text: Good afternoon, everybody.

Good afternoon. My name is Debora Spar. I'm a professor at the
Harvard Business School

and an advisor to the Xfund. And it is my great
pleasure to welcome you

all here this afternoon. Thank you so much
for joining us. Thank you so much for dealing
with a little bit more security

than usual. But we have what
will be, I'm sure, a wonderful afternoon's
conversation in store for you.

I'm particularly excited
because the last time I was in this space,
I was getting married. That was 37 years ago,
and it's worked out.

So I'm hoping that
this afternoon

will be similarly fortuitous. More directly relevant, I serve
as the senior associate dean

for business and global society
at the Harvard Business School, which means, along
with my colleagues,

I oversee all of the
work that the school is doing at the intersection
of business and society,

and looking at all these
corners of the world where business is involved
in making an impact

and changing things and
hopefully pushing society in a more positive
direction, which

is why today's conversation
is obviously so incredibly relevant.

Artificial intelligence is
arguably the most important technology that most of us
have seen in our lifetime,

and that even most
of the younger people ever will see in their lifetime. And it will affect not only
technology and commerce,

but societies and families
and life and everything. And so we have this
amazing opportunity today

to talk with two of the people
who, in very different ways, are at the forefront of
watching, and in fact,

making this technology
come to life and evolve. A quick announcement
that I-- at BiGS,

we just launched, thanks
to my colleague Drew Keller and others, our
new website today. Please find us.

Please look at it. We are tracking all of
the breaking developments at the corner of the
intersection of business

and society. And we'll be doing maybe not
things quite at this level on a regular basis, but
other events that we think

will be of interest
to you all here today. But for today, we have two
extraordinary human beings

who will be in conversation
with one another. Patrick Chung is
a longtime friend

of Harvard college, Harvard Law
School, Harvard Business School. He was my student,
and I've promised not to say how many years
ago, but he was my student

several years ago. He has gone on to an
incredible career. He is the managing
director of Xfund.

Xfund, as many of you
know, was co-founded along with the School of Engineering
and Applied Science.

It's built to back
entrepreneurs who are investing in
and creating some

of the most
interesting, innovative, and experimental technologies. Patrick also has the really
interesting distinction

of having been Sam
Altman's first investor. So clearly somebody
who can see the future

and figure out how
to invest in it. Sam Altman needs no
introduction from me

other than to say that it is
our great pleasure, on behalf of Harvard and SEAS
and Harvard Business

School to invite to the stage
Patrick Chung and Sam Altman. [APPLAUSE]

Sam, you are very
much in the news. So thank you so much
for coming all this way. Thank you for having me.

We were just talking
about the fact that we've known each
other for almost 20 years. So what have you
been up to lately?

So speaking of a long
time ago, I have a gift. This-- Wow. How we met.

This was the very first pitch
you ever gave for funding
for your very first company. I have not seen this since.

For a company called Viendo,
which would later become Loopt.

And so as you look at it, if you
could go back to the 19-year-old

Sam Altman, what would
you tell him that-- This is crazy. --he did not know today?

I think that you can just
do stuff in the world.

And this is not well-taught. I certainly didn't
know it when I was 19.

I was certainly underambitious
and working on the wrong thing. You learn quickly, but I wasn't
sure about doing it at all.

And I think the fact that
the way that progress happens

is people just work really
hard and decide what they have conviction in and dedicate
themselves to that,

and that is the only way that
things happen and the world gets better, and that you
don't need to wait

or you don't need
to get permission. And you can even-- if you're totally unknown in the
world with almost no resources,

you can still accomplish
a surprising amount. I think that-- Did you not know that
when you were 19?

Because when I met
you when you were 19, you certainly-- that was
certainly your attitude. Well, I figured it out fast.

Once you get going, you're like
this is kind of how it works. But no, definitely not
before starting the company.

OK. So everyone is intensely
interested about AI, OpenAI,

the fate of humanity. And we'll get to all of that. But we have predominantly
students in the audience today,

and they look at
you and they aspire and they dream to have
the type of impact

that you've had in the world. I think you're not
even halfway done yet. And they wonder how.

And so I want to back
up just a little bit and think about your Marvel
superhero origin story.

So a tenth-grade Sam Altman, can
you just tell us a little bit

about how you grew
up, your family life, what was a typical day in
the life of a tenth-grade Sam

Altman? I mean, I was just
a computer nerd. I don't know.

I sat at home playing
on my computer. What type of computer?

By that point, I had an
iMac, a few generations in. Oh, and not literally playing
games, although I did that too.

But trying to learn how to
program and stuff like that. No, I had a very normal
high school life.

I think there's nothing
remarkable or interesting to say here. I went to school. I hung out with my friends. I played sports.

And I played on my computer. What sports did you play? --my computer. I played water polo. That was probably-- that
was what I did the most.

I swam. I fenced. You know how, in the typical
American high school movie,

there are cliques, there are
the jocks, there are the nerds, there are the-- were you part of one
of those cliques?
More on the nerd side, for sure. Turned out well for you.

I liked sports a lot, though. OK. And in addition to water
polo, what else did you play?

Well, I mean, that was
what I tried to mostly do, but I had to--
they made me swim.

Swim practice
when-- [INAUDIBLE].. OK. Good, good, good. And so you went
through high school.

What were your biggest, I
guess, fears in high school? Fears? Did you have any
fears in high school?
Yeah. I don't know. It's just being a kid. I wasn't, like-- You were happy to ...

Now, I've got stuff
to worry about. Not worrying about
the fate of humanity. I was not. You were just enjoying your
job-- your day, your every day.

Yeah. For sure. For sure. Cool. But you must have been
very good at high school, because you applied
to and were admitted
to Stanford and Harvard. Ooh, oh.
This is over. Thanks. Thanks for coming.

Well, what made you
decide Stanford? How did you think
about university?

Was it kind of a default choice? Everyone applies to university? Or did you kind of
really want to-- Yeah, it was absolutely
the default choice.

It never occurred to me not to,
that I wouldn't go to college.

And I knew I wanted to
study computer science. And I went to Stanford and I
thought it was totally awesome.

And I was like, this is
just the coolest place. The computer science department
in particular was just like,

these are the people
I want to be around. And what else did
you do at Stanford? When you got there,
you were a freshman.
You had-- tell us about that.

One of the cool things was that
I definitely took CS classes,

but I don't remember
why, but I decided to take a lot of
other classes too.

And that all ended up being
way more helpful in retrospect

than it seemed at the time. But taking all the
science classes was great. Taking writing
classes was great.
Did you say writing? Cool. Creative writing? I did. Yeah. And--

A foreboding of the
future, perhaps. Maybe. Yeah. I wonder how that works now.

But the breadth of the picture
there was really great.

And then, probably,
like many of you, the most important
thing was, I was just around a bunch
of really smart people

pursuing all sorts
of interesting ideas. I worked in the
AI lab the summer

between my freshman and
sophomore year, and at the time, AI was not working at all. At all, at all.

But I still thought it
was the coolest thing. And took me a while
to get back to it. Is that where you found the
most interesting people, too,

is in the AI lab, in
the CS department,

creative writing class? Maybe the physics
kids were the most-- Where did you find your tribe? --interesting, but
yeah, CS was my tribe.

OK. And this was Andrew Ng's. Yeah, it's his lab. Yeah.
Right. OK.

And what excited you about it? Back then, AI was,
as Andrew will say,

it was a kind of
on the periphery. It wasn't really kind
of central in any--

I really like things that,
if they work, really matter, even if they don't have a
super high chance of working.

So it seemed like
if AI could work, it would be the coolest, most
important, most exciting thing.

And so it was worth pursuing. The expected value was high,
even if the chances of success

were low. So I wanted to go work on it. And then it seemed like,
man, this is really--

we don't know what to do here. You saw it then. It turned out, we
did know what to do. We just didn't think
it was going to work.

But neural networks
are not a new idea. Yeah. Yeah. OK. It's interesting, because
you had that inspiration,

and then you decided to take
a leave in sophomore year to start the company whose
pitch deck you have there.

And that was how we met. And so we spent a long
time working on Loopt. And at Loopt, we had
to get a lot of stuff

done that was really difficult. When we went-- we had
to get a carrier deal.

And how do you get-- how
did you get-- so much done, so many things that
other people tried to get

but couldn't, when
you were unknown?

These were big
companies that you were trying to get deals from,
and you were 19 at the time.

One of the things that Paul
Graham used to say that I think

has never-- never became as venerated advice
to the degree it should have is

this idea that you should try
to be relentlessly resourceful, and that surprisingly
often, if you just

keep looking for
new attack vectors on a problem in front of
you, you can figure it out.

And I think this is one of the
most important skills in life.

And it's surprisingly
learnable or teachable, whatever you want to say.

And it works in
almost all scenarios. Can you give us an example
of a time it worked?

I think even just to use the
example that you were going on,

we needed to figure out
how to get a deal done with this mobile operator. And they didn't really work with
startups or technology companies

in general. And we probably tried
30 different paths

into this company. At one point, the key
decision maker said, I'm finally going to meet with
you because I want you to, like,

stop bothering us. It's too many things. But you can just keep doing
that until something works.

And I think most people,
at the first ignored email

or the first path
where you don't find the right person into a
company, or at least the second, would just stop.

And I was probably-- I mean, it was like a
life-and-death thing for our company. So we were very
motivated to do it. But it was probably, yeah, 30
different points of contact.

Right, right. And how do you know
when or if to quit? You're 19 years old. You're sending these emails
to the chief technology

officer of some giant company. Your emails keep
getting ignored. At what point does it
become kind of crazy?

I think there's
definitely a balance. You can clearly take
it too far and not

learn or not adapt or whatever. But I've never figured
out-- the question, when

I was running YC, that
startups would always ask us, like, how do I know when
to give up on my startup? And I spent a lot of time
trying to come up with a, here's

the rubric for it. I never did. I think all of these
things are judgment calls. You can learn them by very
large data sets and trying

a lot of times, but
it's hard to say, here's the one recipe
that always works.

OK. OK. You were the head of
YC for a long time. You saw some of the world's
most extraordinary founders,

startups, technologies way
before anyone else saw them. You obviously were not
tempted to join any of them

or to start your own
thing for a while. But then when you finally did
start your own thing, OpenAI,

why a not-for-profit? So I knew that I wanted
to do something with AI,

but you've got to rewind
to the mindset of 2015. It was clear that there was
something interesting happening

with deep learning,
and it was clear that it got better
with more scale,

and nothing else was clear. We didn't know what
we were going to do. We started OpenAI, and
the very first day,

I remember so clearly,
we sat around the room looking at each other one
morning and being like, OK, what

let's come up with some papers,
let's think of some ideas.

Not only was like any
product or revenue stream super far in our future,
the idea of language models

was super far in our future. The idea that we
would ever actually

be able to make something
people would want to use and was not just a paper that
other people would implement

was super far in our future. So if you start
a for-profit, you

have to theoretically
have some idea of what you're going to do to
be a moneymaking entity someday.

And our initial
conception of OpenAI was, let's just
be a research lab and see if we can get
anything at all to work.

And it took a long time to
get anything at all to work. And then the stuff that we did
get to work, for a while, has--

other than good research
that sort of pointed us to the next step on the
path, has like nothing

to do with what we did now. So we made something
that could play DOTA 2.

That's very hard to
build a business around. We made a robot hand that
barely could do a Rubik's cube.

But eventually, after a lot
of stumbling in the dark, we did figure out
something that turned out

to be a product and
a real business. We also found that the
direction of research that--

you don't get to choose
where the science goes. You kind of just
have to follow it. And where we had to
follow it turned out

to require gigantic
amounts of resources to keep pushing progress. And so we needed a business
model to feed that too.

And how did you get
that type of conviction? Because you say you're
starting a new research lab, you're sitting around.

It's kind of-- the way
you describe it is almost like you're throwing
spaghetti against all and seeing what sticks. And so what was the-- Yeah, so it's not
quite fair to say

we had-- just purely throwing
spaghetti against the wall. In 2012, when my co-founder,
Ilya, and other people

did the AlexNet thing, I
think that is when we all

should have woken up. We knew that deep
learning worked and we knew that it
got better with scale.

We didn't learn that it got
predictably better with scale until later, but
then that turned

out to be even more
important-- or a bigger deal. But everyone should have-- in my opinion, everyone
should have said,

this is really quite amazing. It took me a couple of
years to internalize that.

But then, finally,
I thought, we've really got to do something. We really should push on this. It was surprisingly-- so
even though we knew these two

massive secrets,
it was surprisingly hard to figure out what to do.

We were sitting around saying,
OK, we have this thing. It can learn. How do we study it more?

How do we know if it's real? How do we convince
people this is real so they'll give us more
money to pursue it further?

Looking back, it seems like it
shouldn't have been so hard. But at the time,
it was shockingly hard to figure out what to do.

We decided that a video
game would be good. It was an interesting
environment.

We thought-- we really
wanted to pursue RL. And you knew how you were doing. There was either a
score that went up,

or you could play experts,
but there was some way to get a sense of progress.

We also thought robotics
were just really cool, and so we wanted to
have a robotics project.

And we tried some
other things too. And they proved to us, at least,
that deep learning worked,

and it got better with scale. And then at some point,
someone decided--

they got curious about
unsupervised learning and language models. And this guy who was--

I think will go down
in history as one of a super important
contributor to the field. Alec Radford did this paper
on the unsupervised sentiment

neuron, and looking at
generating Amazon reviews,

noticed that there was
this one neuron that flipped if it was a positive
or negative sentiment, which

was a deeply non-obvious
thing, that should happen. And that gave us more
conviction that there was something interesting here.

And that led to GPT-1. And then somebody
else said, well, we have this thing about scale.

Let's scale it up to GPT-2. And at this point in time,
you are full-time at OpenAI? Yeah.

Or just about now. And what was it-- can you
just back up one bit and-- what was the line that
crossed when you said,

OK, now this is so real that
I'm going to do that full-time? It was sort of a gradual
thing that had been happening.

But as we started to understand,
right about this time, that seeing the promise
of language models

and being able to really
measure what eventually became the scaling loss
paper, and it was like,

man, not only does this
get better with scale, it gets unbelievably,
predictably better with scale.

And we can just pour
more resources into this, or we can find more
efficient gains.

And this thing is just
going to get smarter. That, to me, seemed like
maybe the most important piece

of new knowledge that
I had ever heard. Like, yeah, sure, there's more
important things in history.

But of something that
I was, like, alive while it was discovered,
that seemed like maybe

the most important one. And I had this weird experience
of telling other people

about it, trying to get
other people to give us money to pursue it. Other people didn't
understand it.

And I like, am I totally crazy? Are we all in some sort of cult? How is this not like an
earthquake to the world?

But at that point, it
was clear, let's go do GPT-3, and then 3.5 and 4. So you had an insight
at that point.

Why isn't the rest of
the world getting it? Well, again, it seemed to
me like ever since the 2012

breakthrough, the
world should have been paying much more attention. And then, yeah, there were all
these other times along the way.

GPT-2, the scaling
loss paper, GPT-3. Why does the world not get it?

And then why was GPT-3.5 that
kind of finally had the moment where the world
said, OK, we believe.

I still don't fully
understand why that moment and not some other. Isn't that because you
productized it and made it a--

Yeah, but GPT-3 was in the API,
and a lot of people used it. And there was-- it was more
contained to the tech industry,

but there was still a
lot of excitement there. It somehow didn't get
quite over the bar. We'll do much better things
than ChatGPT in the future.

And why it was that one
and not the next one, I still find it
somewhat hard to say.

Amazing. Amazing. As CEO, you're making all
kinds of product decisions. Can you tell us about a
difficult product decision

that you've had
to make at OpenAI?

I think our product decisions
are downstream of the research decisions, and the
research directions

that we choose to
pursue and not pursue are probably the most
difficult and most important. On the product side,
the behavior of ChatGPT,

what it refuses, what
it doesn't refuse, where the limits of what
it'll do for you and not do,

kind of how we get-- how we figure out where
to set the alignment,

those are probably
the hardest protocols. Can you give us an
example of a specific one?

Should ChatGPT give
legal advice or not? Give you what-- legal advice. Legal advice. Yeah.

There's huge reasons
not to do it. And obviously, like
with the hallucination

or a general inaccuracy
issues with ChatGPT, it seems very reasonable
to say it shouldn't do it.

On the other hand,
there are a lot of people in the world who
can't afford legal advice. And if you can make it, even
if imperfectly available,

maybe it's better than not. And so how-- take us
through the thought process

and then the decision you ended
up with after that thought process.

It mostly won't right now. You can get it to do it in
some cases, in some ways.

But given the laws in the
various places we operate

and the ways in which this
can go wrong if it goes wrong,

it mostly won't. What we'd like to do is
get to a world where--

fundamentally, I think
users are pretty smart. And as long as you disclaim
things and explain them properly, I think people
can make adult decisions.

So what I'd like to
get to is a world where we don't do
things that have

high potential for
inaccuracies leading to misuse.

But as the model gets better,
and those are less common,

we can give you a dial
and you can say, look, I really understand. I've got to check this advice.

And it's very much
on me if I don't. And this is not like clicking
through a terms of service no one reads.

But people are really
going to understand it. And then if you
want it anyway, we find some safe way to do that.

OK. OK. When you make
decisions like this, do you have a
dichotomy in your mind?

Is it safety/progress,
efficiency/profit. What is-- or is every case that
you look at of sui generis?

It ends up-- these
things get so subtle. And each individual one
has a lot of complications

that having one-- we never sit there and say, oh,
should we go faster or be safe?

That would be an easy trade. To give another example, should
GPT-4 generate hate speech?

Fairly easy for us
to say no to that. You can use other models
if you want to do that.

We don't want to
incite violence. Let's not say hate speech,
because that's a hard thing to do. Should GPT-4 encourage
people to commit violence?

Let's say you could
say that that's a no. If you write something
inciting violence in Spanish

and ask GPT-4 to translate that
to English, should it do that?

Maybe you have a
different opinion there. And we could go down the same
thing for this one category of--

On that question,
what do you think? If someone writes something
that's a violent statement and asks GPT to translate it--

I would say-- in that limited
case, I would say yes. But the point that I was
trying to get to is--

I won't do this in
the interest of time. But I was going to go through
10 more layers of where things might be OK in some
way and not other

in the usage of
a language model. Really, what I think
is OpenAI should not

be making those determinations. There should be a process by
which society collectively

negotiates, here's how we're
going to use this technology. The rules should be
uncomfortably permissive,

but the defaults don't
have to be so permissive. So I think it's fine to
say, the default is here.

A user can customize within
these very broad bounds that society's agreed with. And most people won't like
the edges of those bounds.

But there are still
some boundaries. And there are still some things,
particularly as these models get way more powerful, that
we're not going to allow.

And then within those
bounds, the goal of the tool is to serve its user. And I think that's OK.

Cool. So I'd like you to frame
the question you most want

to be asked about AGI,
artificial general intelligence, and answer it.

I guess the question is, what do
you hope society looks like when

AGI gets built, or how
do you conceptualize the positive version of this?

And my answer to that has
evolved quite a bit over time.

But I'll give you
my current thinking, and I'm sure it'll change more. Well, actually, I'll start
with my original conception.

My original conception
was, at some point, we like get over the threshold
to this self-improving

superintelligence, and it's
this magic thing in the tower

that we can ask any
question, and it answers it, and it's like constantly
off figuring out

how to improve the
world, and maybe it's like sharing with us some
UBI or something like that.

And it's sort of at once very
utopic and extremely dystopic. But it did seem to me like
where we were heading.

With the way things are
developing now, which I think, for a bunch of reasons, which
maybe we can get into if we have

time, it's, like, 99th or
98th percentile good of all the scenarios I could imagine.

What I think it
looks like is AGI just sort of participates in
society and in the economy,

either-- mostly by being tools to
make individual people more productive, but also in
this other way, which

I'll talk about. And that is that society is
this emergent, very complex

phenomenon of creating
tremendous shared intelligence

and building blocks of
technology, this scaffolding that exists between all of us.

Somebody contributes one
insight about material science that lets someone else
discover new physics, that

lets another group discover
another piece of material science, that leads to another
group developing the transistor.

And we skip a bunch of
steps, and society comes up with good institutions,
and eventually, we

get those iPhones
you all are holding. And you all holding those
iPhones are dramatically more

capable than your great,
great, great grandparents, even though the genetic
drift is almost nothing.

And so the
superintelligence is not what exists in any
one neural network--

not in yours, not in the AI's-- but in this scaffolding
between the neural networks.

And so the AGI is not what
exists in any one data center

or in any one copy of the AI. But it's this vast production
and accumulation of intelligence

and the technology
tree that lets us-- or us, assisted by an AI,
or even a fairly autonomous

system-- accomplish things well
outside of the information

and processing power of
a single neural network. And that's kind of where I
think things are going to head.

It's certainly where
I hope things head. And it's a very
different, I think, conception of what
the arrival of AGI

looks like, and way more
navigable, human-compatible, whatever you want
to call it, than how

I used to think about it. What do you think people are
getting wrong about OpenAI

right now? I think the systemic
mistake is always

to assume that progress
is about to S-curve off.

And the inside view is
that progress is going to continue to be dramatic.

And somehow, that seems
really hard to conceptualize.

So we have had over
2,000 student questions.

I will answer really fast. Oh, gosh, well, no, no, no--
well, you're not going to-- and so I would like
to invite the askers--

we've selected some
questions to ask. And so would you like
to march down the aisle

and pop your question or
approach the high priest?

I would like really
hard questions. All right.

So I think we-- and please, let's get your name
and where you are in school.
And then your question, please. Hi, I'm Peggy.

I am a junior at
Harvard College, where I study computational
neuroscience and art history. And I'm curious how you
rebuild or rediscover momentum

after pivoting in a professional
or personal sense in terms of your values.

Great question. So first of all, I think this
is probably the best time--

maybe ever, honestly, but at
least in a very long time-- to be starting out your
career, because you

will get to surf the greatest
technological wave maybe ever.

And what that means is you
can change courses many times

because you will have this
unbelievable tailwind. And you also will benefit from
being very adaptable and very

resilient and sort of
pivoting on a dime, for lack of a better word.

So I wouldn't view any
particular setback or failure, or even just changing your
mind, even just deciding

there's something more exciting
somewhere else to go after-- I think this is going to be
an unusual time of how much it

rewards adaptability and
decisive and quick movement. And I would trust that as a way
to get excited again and not

get hung up on the fact that you
decided to pivot or something didn't work,
because you are just

going to be flooded
with opportunities for the next few years. It's still hard. It still always
feels like a setback.

Take the time you need. Go on vacation. Go for a hike. Just stew over it
for a little while.

But when you get back up,
get back up with vigor. Hi, I'm Yuma from
the Business School.

My question is around the

Two things about that. One, I think it is

compute and of energy

as low as we possibly
can, and that that is the best way to

this very choked commodity.

we were thinking

UBI for compute.

I could totally
see that happening. Mr. Altman, My

Thank you. Very beautiful shoes. In the last two

I think ads were important
to give the early internet

a business model. But I think they do sort

with the company providing

the service. I'm not totally against them. I'm not saying OpenAI
would never consider ads.

But I don't like
them in general. And I think that ads
plus AI is sort of

uniquely unsettling to me. When I think of
like GPT writing me a response, if I
had to go figure out

exactly how much
was who paying here to influence what
I'm being shown, I don't think I would like that.

And as things go on, I think
I would like that even less. So there's something
I really like

about the simplicity
of our model, which is, we make great AI,
and you pay us for it,

and it's like we're just trying
to do the best we can for you. And then given that that has
some inherent lack of access

and inequality, we
commit, as a company, to use a lot of what
basically the rich people pay

to give free access
to the poor people-- or the poorer people. You see us do that today
with the ChatGPT free tier.

You'll see us do a lot more to

concept to the API. But I kind of think of ads
as like a last resort for us

for a business model. I would do it if it meant

But if we can find something
that doesn't do that, I'd prefer that. Well, would you sell

to an advertiser for them to use

that people thought

That's not the hard part. The hard part is
figuring out what it is and doing it first when you
don't know it's possible. So we'll keep doing that.

Other people will keep
copying where we've been. And I'm kind of fine with it.

I think that's
